SUNDAY CHURCH SERVICES

ST. ALTIN'S AND ST. MATTHIAS' PARISHES.

(From Thursday) 6th May—Sunday Services conducted by Rev. A. W. Hume.

St. Matthias' Church—8.45 a.m.—Rev. Canon PFEIFFER.

St. Patrick's Church—9 a.m.—Rev. Mrs. Macdonald.

St. Andrew's—10.30 a.m.—Mr. Maurice.

St. John's—1 p.m.—Mr. Skelly.

St. Joseph's—4 p.m.—Ven. Archdeacon McKay.

St. Peter's—5.30 p.m.—Rev. Mrs. Macdonald.

St. Paul's—6.15 p.m.—Rev. Mrs. Macdonald.

Methodist Church—St. David's—Rev. Prichard.

Lucas and Webster—9 a.m.—Rev. Mrs. Smith.

Emu Church—Rev. Wilson.

End—Rev. C. C. STEPHENSON, Pastor-in-Charge.

FRIDAY, MAY 13, 1867.

THE LIQUOR QUESTION.

The Calgary Club, of the Irish club, was met for breakfast on April 3rd.

In no place in the Northwest, perhaps, are the evils of the present system so strikingly prominent as in Calgary.

It has been said that no place is more evil than Quebec, and mention made of its saloon and gambling houses.

That is true, but Calgary holds an equal or an even greater preponderance of these evils.

The Vice-Bishop visited Calgary last year and spoke from the pulpit against the consumption of liquor.

The Catholic ladies of Calgary have formed an association to promote temperance among their members.

The question now arises, How can we combat the vice? What is the best plan?

The Catholic ladies have taken a direct stand against liquor.

They have held public meetings and have petitioned the government for legislation.

They have also formed an association to assist in the formation of temperance societies.

The question now arises, How can we combat the vice? What is the best plan?

The Catholic ladies have taken a direct stand against liquor.

They have held public meetings and have petitioned the government for legislation.

They have also formed an association to assist in the formation of temperance societies.

MR. JUSTICE MCGUIRE.

Speaking of the judge appointed for this district, Mr. Justice Why (Liberal) of the 25th, says:

"It is now in order for the friends of Mr. T. H. Maguire, Q. C., to congratulate him on his appointment to the position of judge of the Supreme Court of the District of Saskatchewan, N.W.T. The choice was made at an early time, and was confirmed at the Cabinet meeting on Saturday, and the Governor formally gave his consent. It can hardly be doubted that this is an accomplished fact, and only a matter of time, possibly less than a month, until Mr. McGivney ceases to be a member of the Kingdom's service.

Appointments to public office now, days, civil or judicial, are influenced by political considerations. The appointments in the Northwest territories having been made, correctly, the present Government was not only justified in doing it, but it was rewarded by appointment to the same those who were friendly to it. Over the administration of the new territories, there will preside over the Albertans, Judges McLeod and Robson; over Saskatchewan, Judge Whyte. We have no reason to object to the selection of these men, and, the territorial council has, in honouring a serving member of the Conservative party done them also a great service. We do not disparage the abilities of the learned gentlemen and his fitness for the discharge of the duties that have been assigned to him. Mr. Maguire has always been a useful citizen. He has given his attention to a multitude of matters, and he is very likely to be heard when he begins to argue with credit for his fidelity. A member of the bar, of the Committee of the law society, and a member of the church, he has been ready to do whatever he thought was best, and he has got into the habit of taking a leading position in all of them. Political, legal and other friends will, of course, congratulate him, but the press congratulates him as a journalist. It may not be generally known, but he is a fact reporter, that he has had a couple of years acting as editor of the News and rendered a service the termination of which our contemporary newspapers regret. He is a man of well read politi sly, and wrote as the better second journalism of today are writing. He has been able to attract the people in the topics of the house. He did not oblige his personal ability to colour his columns, and did make free with the personality of others, and as a result no one could have enjoyed the reading of his columns. He is the second person connected with the press of Kingston to ascend the bench; the first was Mr. Justice Whyte, and Mr. Joseph Ryan, whose pen, while a student and barrister-at-law in Kingston, through the medium of the News, was engaged in framing newspaper attacks, the pungency of some of which has been felt even to this day.

EDITORIAL NOTES.

Our old friend is enjoying good health and spirits, and seems fair to lead his party to victory at the next election.

Sir Richard Cartwright thinks one Senator is enough for the Northwest, while Mr. Blake does not think so. The latter is right, and the former is wrong.

The Regina Leader says—A question or two days ago about the House of Commons being able to add members to the best looking man in the House, and it was unanimously decided Mr. Fisher was the best looking man, and to say that Mr. Macdonald was absent at the time.

Rumour is abroad again against watery stories about intended Indian and Half-breed ridings. Because a few Indians and half-breeds are not entitled to vote this time of the year, and a few lazy Metis are kicking because the Government has not given them the land they ask for, and a great deal more than that, there is no inducement for them to go and vote. They are lazy, and those who circulate such stories have little wit with those who believe them should get third rate jobs, and be sent to the Governor's grave in the place where the hair is thin. This process is warranted to prevent sniping.

The St. John's sealing steamers have done very badly this year.

TERRITORIAL NEWS.

EDMONTON.

From the Bulletin, April 16th.

R. Logan and J. Fraser returned from Beaver Lake last Saturday last. Mr. Logan purchased Colin Fraser's herd of moose last winter near the lake, for $100. Many were killed around the lake when Messrs. Fraser and Logan were there. A few geese had arrived also, twenty-five were killed, and old and young, one was killed while they were near the lake, and six are reported in the same locality.

The usual police horses and stores at the Saskatchewan was well attended, a number of parties from Edmonton, Fort Qu'Appelle, Clavet Bar being present. G. A. Bird, who was formerly bidding was spirited and the prices realized high. Nine horses were sold at $400, ranging from $300 to $500, average price being $385. Twenty saddles were sold from $4 to $10, three guns from $75 to $125, and there was a large number of boots and shoes, valises, bottles, etc. The total amount realized was $750.

BATTLEFORD.

From the Herald of April 23.

A neat marble tablet has been placed in St. George's Church to the memory of Mr. Robert K. Wilson, chief of the Metis' Indians in 1885. It was erected by the fellow employees of the deceased in telegraphing the news of his death.

The Mr. K. division are raising up their wagons and transport outfit preparatory to taking the route to the North West Mounted Police. Their departure is not yet determined on.

Tenders are asked for the erection of a bridge across the Battle river.

The police was called last week that a small posse had made its appearance on a Sweet Grass reserve, on Battle river, and had arrested a man named Smith. He found that the suspected case was only one of cutaneous eruption. The Indians were very frightened, and the man was quite quiet in his own mind, as he had already and the small posse did not fear taking it again.

GENERAL NEWS.

CANADIAN.

One hundred and four degrees were given in Macdonald University last year.

Gustave Charles August Bujon was sentenced to the penitentiary for 30 days, charged with defrauding the public in Belgium to the extent of $100,000.

The Ottawa committee reports the April 10th, that the city's tax revenue for April was $14,430 last year. At Montreal they were $63,908, against $37,708, and inland revenue $162,314, against $100,000.

Mrs. Rattray of Hamilton, attempted to shoot her husband on the 30th. The attempt was successful.

A fire recently destroyed Mr. Gordon's store and an adjoining dwelling house, loss heavy.

Fred Morley of Mrs. Hon. Oliver has been appointed sheriff of Toronto.

Bishop Binney, of Nova Scotia, is dead.

Territorial stonemasons, carpenters and plumbers have gone out on strike.

Rev. Dr. Dowling, of Paris, has been consecrated bishop of Peterborough in succession to Bishop Macdonald, at St. Mary's church, Hamilton.

Capt. Samuel Bedson has been appointed adjutant of the 3rd.

A catalogue prepared by the Department of Agriculture on Saturday says five steamers left Liverpool this week, bound for Canada, carrying 2,276 tons English, a large proportion agricultural and many with capital.

C. Neill, prominent detective, died at Regina on the 30th.

Fears are entertained at Amberstouch, Ont., that the scholastic Louis O'Neill has gone down with all his board.

The late Alexander Mitchell, of Milne, leaves an estate worth eight million dollars.

Specialists from Paris declare that poppy fever is gaining ground in France rapidly.

There is an epidemic of diphtheria among Nancy, Troy, and Spalding, and the poppy fever demand the liberation of Alsace Lorraine from the German yoke.

We are prepared to Contract for Buildings at cheap rates any firm in Town

Builders paying Cash or giving good security for LARGE Orders, will have a reduction made.

MOORE & MACDOWALL.
TOWN COUNCIL

An adjourned meeting of the Town Council was held in the Council Chamber on Monday evening last.

Present—Mayor Macarthur and Counsellors Agnew, Bain, Braden and Stevenson.

The minutes of the last meeting were read and adopted.

Coun. Agnew introduced a by-law to amend By-law No. 18.

A resolution was received from Joseph Courtenay, J. R. McPaul, L. Clarke and others, asking for certain improvements in the east end of town. Referred to the Board of Works.

A communication was received from Mr. Gibson, District Surveyor of Telegraph poles in reference to removal of telegraph poles on River Street.

Coun. Agnew was instructed to see that the poles put in the proper place when removed.

On motion of Couns. Stewart and Bain, two members, Couns. Agnew and Agnew were appointed a committee to wait upon Provost Dominance in reference to the cemetery.

Street Inspector reported, after viewing the matters referred to him on Kay street, two on Queen and two on King street. Referred to the Board of Works.

On motion of Couns. Stewart and Bain, the Health Inspector was instructed that he would examine on or before the 10th day of January next.

On motion of Couns. Bain and Agnew, the Mayor and Couns. Stewart and Bain ordered the Secretary to be directed to draft a petition to the Governor General in Council for a grant of land on the north side of the river for the purpose of a public park for the town, and to present the same at the next meeting of the Council.

The by-law to amend By-law No. 18 was read a first and second time.

On motion of Couns. Agnew and Stewart, the Mayor was requested to send a Committee of the Whole to consider the whole of the petition by law No. 18, Coun. Bain moved that they do.

After considering the by-law the committee rose and the chairman reported, when the by-law was read a third time and a first and second time when the Council resolved itself into a Committee of the Whole to consider the petition by law No. 18, Agnew moved that the by-law was not fit for the consideration of the Committee.

The by-law to regulate the licensing of hotels, restaurants, saloons, places of public resort or accommodation, places having wine and spirit licences, etc., etc., was read a second time and ordered to be signed and numbered.

TELEGRAPHIC.

QUEENSTOWN, May 9.

An experimental line will likely be located near Winnipeg.

Perley and Grindley, two gentlemen largely interested in aviation, visited here recently. They are interested in the extension of the Canadian Pacific Railway's branch line to the Souris district.

Nothing further has been done in disallowances since Mr. Macdonald visited here after the legislature, but the entire government could not well grant a private interview, but if they desired to see us we would arrange another time.

At the request of Mr. Van Horne, Home will visit Montreal to adjust freight rates. Freight rates will likely be made national. Mr. Macdonald, Carling, of East Room, has introduced a bill to repeal the Scott Act.

Chimney bulkheads being public property have been run in thirty yards.

Capt. Price resumed the debate in the British House of Commons last evening on the subject of the proposed House appoint a committee to examine into the charges of falsification made by Mr. Gladstone's amendment and in its rejection by a vote of 317 to 233. Sir John Lubbock said that no breach of privilege had been committed when the motion was then adopted.

One hundred and seventy-eight men were employed in the Namakwa coal mine by fire damp.

TOWN MATTERS.

The order given by the Town Council that persons having muncie, fifth and sixth stories under their premises must deposit an $8 insurance fund for each street, must be a surprise to most people. Certainly of making a nuisance is one of the things which ought to be taken care of in the place referred to. If our Council are desirous of doing something to improve the sanitary condition of the health, we beg to inform them that there are three dead horses in the bluff in front of the school house and that it would be well to have them buried before the hot weather comes on.

The resolution stated at the last week's meeting of the Council instructing the Clerk to communicate with Mr. Macdonald and ask whether the Government intended to furnish any assistance for Government buildings here, did not do much credit to the former. When asked why they would not assist us in building public buildings within our corporation, we think it is the least we could do to assist in the erection of such buildings as thing as being too greedy and we are afraid this is a case in point. Besides we are not sure that the Government would ever assist in the erection of such buildings as those where the Government supply free protection for Government buildings. If they would do so, and allow us to use the building, we would like to be assisted.

The by-law to regulate the licensing of hotels, restaurants, saloons, places of public resort or accommodation, places having wine and spirit licences, etc., etc., was read a second time and ordered to be signed and numbered.

The new steel bridge on the M. & N. W. railroad over the Mississippi river has been completed. It is the only steel bridge on the road and is a splendid piece of work. The total cost of the bridge will be between $30,000 and $30,000. The first train to run across it was a special combination E. Baker, Mr. Spencer Folsom, and other officials of the road. An extension of ten miles of the road is now under way.

The Spanish Government of Santo Domingo, with 800 regular soldiers, attacked several thousand rebels at Monte Morro, defeated them after a hard battle, capturing the guns of the insurgents and killing many prisoners. The rebels of Monte Morro were routed and burned, only the Chinese residents being spared. The natives claimed that the Spaniards used cannon.

Hod carriers in Chicago have made a demand for an increase in wages from 22 to 25 cents an hour.

AMERICAN AND FOREIGN.

A fire in Kankakee, Ill., on May 1st, destroyed property to the value of sixty thousand dollars.

Gen. de Bourgoing, French Minister of War, has published a decree in the war pamphlet entitled "The Next Franco-German Battle." It embodies the theories of French military training and tactics put into practice by Bourgoing since he became Minister of War. The publication also tends to remove the wax from, and the fear of foreign invasion which is so apt to inspire confidence in the prowess of the army.
